CONCLUSION: Questions of procedure rejected;Violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . PERSON , a NORP national born in DATE , died on DATE after several stays in hospital . He lived in GPE with his parents . He received a ORG allowance of MONEY per month as a disabled adult and did not pursue an occupation .

CARDINAL . PERSON was a haemophiliac and had undergone several blood transfusions , in particular DATE and DATE at the LAW - Antoine hospital in GPE . On DATE it was discovered that he was HIV ( Human Immunodeficiency Virus ) positive .

CARDINAL . As other haemophiliacs had been infected by HIV , ORG tried to obtain compensation from the State for the damage suffered by its members who had been so infected . Since it was unable to secure a settlement , the ORG recommended to its members that they should institute proceedings before the DATE limitation period expired .

CARDINAL . PERSON applied for legal aid on DATE ; he was granted it on DATE . On CARDINAL May he filed an application in ORG for the annulment of the ministerial decision and for an order requiring the ORG to pay him compensation of MONEY plus statutory interest .

The applicant requests ORG to give to the Minister for Health , ORG and ORG formal notice that he is to produce his defence submissions speedily , and maintains his previous submissions . "
The medical certificate in question , which had been drawn up by Professor PERSON , stated :

CARDINAL . The Minister for ORG and ORG replied by a memorial dated DATE , lodged on CARDINAL DATE and communicated to the applicant on DATE . In it he called upon the court to " dismiss the applicant ’s claim " , but added :

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted his reply , in which he asked that the application for an expert opinion be rejected . He stated :

As the causal connection has been clearly established by the evidence in the applicant ’s file , the only question to be ruled on by the court is whether the Minister was negligent .

This assessment of whether the delay in taking the measures for protection of public health which he was under a duty to take was negligent may be made in the light of the evidence before the court , which can in addition request the communication of the expert opinion of Professor PERSON before the tribunal de grande instance .

On DATE , CARDINAL May and DATE , the President of the relevant section of ORG asked the Minister or the Director of ORG , as the case may be , for certain information and documents ; they replied to these requests on DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE . Chronology of the facts and decisions with regard to haemophiliacs " ; ORG ( GPE ) had drawn up this report on DATE , at the request of the Minister for ORG and Integration and the Deputy Minister for Health on DATE . CARDINAL . The hearing in ORG was held on DATE . DATE the court dismissed PERSON claims on the following grounds :

Mr [ X ] claims that the ORG is liable on account of alleged negligence on the part of the Minister responsible for ORG in exercising the powers of health policy vested in him pursuant to the combined provisions of Articles L. CARDINAL and L. CARDINAL of LAW ; in support of his submissions the applicant argues that the Minister delayed prohibiting the distribution to haemophiliacs of blood products contaminated with the human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) although , DATE , the process of heat- treating blood made it possible to inactivate the virus ; he further complains that the relevant ministry did not inform the haemophiliac community of the serious risks incurred through the use of such products ; the ministerial authority is also criticised for having , in the exercise of its powers of health policy , on DATE , postponed until DATE the ending of reimbursement by health insurance funds of the blood products used by the haemophiliacs , a measure which it is agreed amounted in fact to a prohibition owing to the high cost of the products known as ` factors ORG and GPE ;

In a new pleading filed on DATE , Mr [ X ] argues in the alternative that the ORG is also liable on the ground of liability for presumed negligence in the organisation and functioning of the public service of blood transfusion ; he further alleges that the ORG is liable on the basis of the risk arising from the reckless activity of the public blood transfusion service ;
The liability of the ORG

The public blood transfusion service in GPE is run by private associations , having none of the prerogatives of a public authority , which are moreover exclusively exercised by the ORG as holder of the specific powers of health policy ( as indicated above ) ; the ORG is , however , neither prescriber , nor manufacturer , nor supplier of the offending blood products [ ; ] accordingly its liability may be incurred only on account of negligent acts committed in the exercise of its regulatory powers and it is for the applicant to prove that such negligence occurred ;

The investigation shows that progress in scientific knowledge concerning HIV , whose first pathological manifestations appeared DATE , from the point of view both of its transmission and of the techniques for its inactivation , was very slow and was the subject of controversy within the scientific community itself ; in particular , although the process of heat - treating blood was approved by the NORP health authorities as early as DATE , this technique was developed to combat the hepatitis virus ; its effectiveness against HIV remained purely hypothetical for DATE ; moreover , some researchers feared that the use of this technique would be likely to have an adverse effect on the ORG clotting and auto - immunising property ; although such fears proved unfounded , an assessment of the liability incurred must necessarily be made on the basis of the scientific knowledge available at the time ; in confining itself to issuing , by way of a circular on DATE , a recommendation concerning the selection of blood donors , for the information of donors and doctors at transfusion centres about the potential risks of infection , the administrative authority did not therefore commit a negligent act such as to render it liable ; the same applies , for identical reasons , to the lack of information furnished to the haemophiliac community concerning the risks to which they were exposed ;

However , after this date scientific knowledge constantly progressed ; the ORG , which was moreover an ex officio member of ORG , could not fail to have been aware both of such progress and of the spread of the epidemic , and it could not plead the lack of availability of reliable HIV screening tests in order to justify its " wait - and - see " policy once cases of AIDS in the haemophiliac community had revealed the existence of a statistically significant causal relationship between the administration of blood product derivatives and HIV infection ; even granted that there remained some uncertainties concerning hypothetical side effects of the heat - treatment technique at DATE , the revelation of the scale of the predicted health catastrophe demanded that the distribution of contaminated blood products be halted rigorously and without delay ;

The investigation , and in particular the report of ORG , shows that the ministerial authority was informed at the latest and in unequivocal terms on DATE of the very strong probability that in the GPE region " all blood products prepared from pools of NORP donors [ were ] currently contaminated " ; the author of the report appositely noted that the importance of this message did not seem to have been perceived ; in failing to adopt immediately a measure prohibiting the distribution of such products , either by legislation or taking appropriate practical measures , the authority responsible for health policy thus committed a negligent act such as to render the ORG liable ;

Moreover , when on DATE the authority correctly assessed the danger to health in deciding that non - heat- treated blood products should no longer be reimbursed , it saw fit to postpone the date on which its decision was to take effect until DATE ; given the certainty established at that time that all blood products were contaminated , it can not , in order to justify opting for a transitional period , plead either the consent of the haemophiliac community , which had in any case not been accurately informed of the scale of the catastrophe , or an alleged need to maintain CARDINAL self - sufficiency , while decontaminated products were available on the international market ;

On the other hand , the physiological consequences of re- infection of those who were already HIV positive on DATE , made possible through the shortcomings of the ORG referred to above , are entirely hypothetical in the present state of scientific knowledge ; consequently , the alleged damage from re - infection is purely contingent and can not give rise to a right to compensation ;

It follows from all the foregoing that the ORG is liable in respect of haemophiliacs who were infected by HIV in the course of transfusion of non - heat - treated blood products , during the period of liability defined above , DATE and DATE ;

Although the ORG , as indicated above , is neither the prescriber , nor the manufacturer , nor the supplier of the offending blood products , and although it is for the courts alone to assess whether the blood transfusion centres have incurred liability , nonetheless the task of such centres is to provide a public service , and accordingly there are grounds for the administrative court to order the ORG to pay compensation for the whole of the damage suffered ;
The causal relationship between the damage suffered by Mr [ X ] and the liability of the ORG

Even if Mr [ X ] , who received for the treatment of his haemophilia not clotting factors ORG or ORG , which it has been established above were negligently distributed , but A cryoprecipitates , may validly claim that the ORG is liable , the case - file shows that he was found to be HIV positive on DATE , a condition , which , taking into account an irreducible period of seroconversion , must be regarded as having actually arisen prior to the beginning of the period of the ORG ’s liability defined above , and consequently the submissions of his application must be dismissed ; "
